intro: Sebaea emirnensis, commonly known as the Persian waxplant, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Iran. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, waxy, and often colorful bracts that surround its small flowers. The plant typically grows as an upright shrub with thick, fleshy stems and leaves that are usually succulent in nature. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a hardy species that can thrive in dry conditions. The bracts of Sebaea emirnensis are not only ornamental but also play a role in attracting pollinators to the plant.
